RECREATIONAL.summary: It is not legal for adults to possess cannabis in Texas. State law classifies cannabis (marijuana) as a controlled substance, and possession of any usable quantity is a criminal offense, regardless of age. There are no exemptions for adult recreational possession, and penalties range from a misdemeanor to a felony depending on the amount possessed.
RECREATIONAL.gov_quote: "Except as authorized by this chapter, a person commits an offense if the person knowingly or intentionally possesses a usable quantity of marihuana."

MEDICAL.summary: It is not legal for medical marijuana patients to possess cannabis (unrestricted-THC marijuana) in Texas. Texas law only allows registered patients to possess 'low-THC cannabis' (not more than 1% THC by weight) prescribed under the Compassionate Use Program. Possession of cannabis with higher THC content remains illegal for all persons, including medical patients.
MEDICAL.validation_notes: Research verification confirmed the accuracy of the report's claims. Texas Health and Safety Code defines 'low-THC cannabis' as containing not more than 1% THC by weight, and no statutory exemption exists for possession of cannabis with higher THC content by medical patients.
